S3.T1.table:
Symbol Explanation
ℒℒ\mathcal{L} Loss function (e.g., cross-entropy).
R𝑅R Maximum training rounds.
T𝑇T Number of iterations in each round.
K𝐾K, Kmsuperscript𝐾𝑚K^{m} Number of devices (in factory m𝑚m).
L𝐿L Number of devices to be selected per factory.
Lrndsubscript𝐿rndL_{\mathrm{rnd}} Number of devices to be randomly pre-sampled per factory.
Lselsubscript𝐿selL_{\mathrm{sel}} Number of devices to be selected by GBP-CS per factory.
M𝑀M Number of factories (also the number of groups).
F𝐹F Number of classification classes.
η𝜂\eta Local learning rate.
ωtsubscript𝜔𝑡\omega_{t} Parameters of the global ML model at t𝑡t-th iteration.
ωtmsuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑚\omega_{t}^{m} Parameters of the ML model on BS m𝑚m at t𝑡t-th iteration.
ωtm,ksuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑚𝑘\omega_{t}^{m,k} Parameters of the local ML model on device k𝑘k in factory m𝑚m at t𝑡t-th iteration.
𝒟m,ksuperscript𝒟𝑚𝑘\mathcal{D}^{m,k} Local dataset of device k𝑘k in factory m𝑚m.
𝒟tm,ksubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑚𝑘𝑡\mathcal{D}^{m,k}_{t} A mini-batch data of device k𝑘k in factory m𝑚m at t𝑡t-th iteration.
Nm,ksuperscript𝑁𝑚𝑘N^{m,k} Size of local dataset of device k𝑘k in factory m𝑚m.
n𝑛n, nm,ksuperscript𝑛𝑚𝑘n^{m,k} Batch data size (of device k𝑘k in factory m𝑚m).
nmsuperscript𝑛𝑚n^{m} Total size of data batches in factory m𝑚m.
𝐚tm,ksubscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑚𝑘𝑡\mathbf{a}^{m,k}_{t} Data size vector of F𝐹F label classes of mini-batch data 𝒟tm,ksubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑚𝑘𝑡\mathcal{D}^{m,k}_{t}.
𝐀tmsubscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑚𝑡\mathbf{A}^{m}_{t} Data size matrix of 𝐚tm,ksubscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑚𝑘𝑡\mathbf{a}^{m,k}_{t} of Km−Lrndsuperscript𝐾𝑚subscript𝐿rndK^{m}-L_{\mathrm{rnd}} devices.
𝐛tmsubscriptsuperscript𝐛𝑚𝑡\mathbf{b}^{m}_{t} Total data size vector of the pre-sampled Lrndsubscript𝐿rndL_{\mathrm{rnd}} devices.
𝒞msuperscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}^{m} Set of all devices in factory m𝑚m.
𝒞tmsubscriptsuperscript𝒞𝑚𝑡\mathcal{C}^{m}_{t} Set of L𝐿L selected devices in factory m𝑚m at t𝑡t-th iteration.
𝒫m,ksuperscript𝒫𝑚𝑘\mathcal{P}^{m,k} Local data distribution of device k𝑘k in factory m𝑚m.
𝒫tm,ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑚𝑘𝑡\mathcal{P}^{m,k}_{t} Local data distribution of mini-batch data 𝒟tm,ksubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑚𝑘𝑡\mathcal{D}^{m,k}_{t}.
𝒫tmsubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑚𝑡\mathcal{P}^{m}_{t} Mean data distribution of 𝒫tm,ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑚𝑘𝑡\mathcal{P}^{m,k}_{t} over selected devices 𝒞tmsubscriptsuperscript𝒞𝑚𝑡\mathcal{C}^{m}_{t}.
𝒫realsuperscript𝒫real\mathcal{P}^{\mathrm{real}} Real-world global data distribution.
references: We summarize the main symbols used in this paper in Table I. The framework and workflow of the proposed FedGS are illustrated in Fig. 2.

S7.T2.caption: TABLE II: Test accuracy, test loss and convergence speed of FedGS vs ten federated approaches.
S7.T2.table:
Test Accuracy Test Loss Rounds To 82%
FedAvg (Baseline) 82.1% 0.587 478
FedProx 82.0% 0.586 497
IDA 81.0% 0.628 ×\times
IDA+INTRAC 81.0% 0.618 ×\times
IDA+FedAvg 80.5% 0.687 ×\times
CGAU 83.3% 0.509 202
FedMMD 83.0% 0.564 378
FedFusion+Conv 81.7% 0.624 ×\times
FedFusion+Multi 82.0% 0.591 486
FedFusion+Single 80.7% 0.627 ×\times
FedAvgM 84.4% 0.820 68
FedAdagrad 83.8% 0.583 264
FedAdam 85.0% 0.662 71
FedYogi 84.6% 0.590 76
FedGS 86.0% 0.435 147
references:
Comparison among FedGS and other federated approaches.
We take ten advanced federated approaches for comparison to show the state-of-the-art performance of the proposed FedGS in the presence of non-i.i.d. data. The test accuracy, test loss, and training rounds required to reach the accuracy of 82% are listed in Table II, and detailed training curves are given in Fig. 6. Unless otherwise specified, all the comparison approaches use the local epoch e=5𝑒5e=5 by default. In the following, we will compare these approaches and analyze their results, respectively.

To sum up, FedAvgM, FedAdagrad, FedAdam, and FedYogi are generally better than other comparison approaches (some of which cannot even reach the accuracy of 82%, marked with “×\times” in Table II). Instead, FedGS achieves the state-of-the-art accuracy of 86.0%, which is 3.9% higher than the baseline and 3.5% higher than the averaged accuracy. In addition, FedGS can also reach the accuracy of 82% in only 147 rounds, which is 3.3×\times faster than FedAvg and reduces training rounds by 59% on average. These comprehensive experiments prove the effectiveness and efficiency of FedGS.
